gold_summary:
||startoftext||The patient is a 46-year-old male who was admitted for alcohol withdrawal. He has a history of alcohol abuse and has experienced withdrawal seizures in the past. He drinks 16 drinks of vodka daily and had 6 drinks today, which led to symptoms such as insomnia, seeing flashes of "demonic faces," and dreams of being levitated by devils. He was treated with benzodiazepines and had no further seizures in the hospital. His roommate, who was also an inpatient for detox, left the hospital against medical advice to be with him in the emergency department.

The patient's past medical history includes alcohol abuse with a history of withdrawal seizures, foot surgery, and hand surgery. His family history is significant for alcoholism, with his grandfather and many other family members affected.

The patient's physical examination was notable for poor dentition, thrush on his tongue, and a trace fine tremor. His laboratory results showed elevated liver enzymes, likely due to fatty deposition in the liver.

The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of alcohol abuse and was advised to start outpatient treatment within one week of discharge. He was also prescribed medications including folic acid, multivitamins, thiamine, and nystatin oral suspension. ||endoftext||

gold_summary:
||startoftext||The patient is a 79-year-old female who was admitted to the plastic surgery service for a left mastectomy with tissue expander placement and sentinel node lymph biopsy. She has a history of previous bilateral breast cancer, breast cancer, hypertension, macular degeneration, compression fracture T7, thyroid disease, and reflux. She is a non-smoker and occasional drinker. 

The patient's presenting symptoms were recurrent left breast cancer, and she underwent a left simple mastectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy with immediate tissue expander insertion. 

The patient's diagnosis is breast cancer. She was prescribed medications including lisinopril, oxycodone, Tylenol, docusate sodium, and cefadroxil. 

The patient was discharged home with service and was advised to follow certain instructions, including cleaning around the drain site, stripping drain tubing, and recording output. She was also advised to resume her regular diet, avoid lifting heavy objects, and take her prescribed medications as ordered. ||endoftext||

gold_summary:
||startoftext||The patient is a 46-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with chest pain and shortness of breath. He has a history of diabetes, anxiety, depression, and hidradenitis suppuritiva, and is currently taking Humira for his condition. He was transferred from another hospital with a diagnosis of NSTEMI and was started on heparin and morphine for pain management. 

The patient's past medical history includes depression, anxiety, genital warts, c. diff, fatty liver, DM2, HLD, thyroid nodule, and anal condyloma. He has also had multiple surgeries, including a L4-S1 diskectomy/fusion, hemorrhoidectomy, and excision of anal condylomata.

The patient's physical exam was notable for a large ulcerated lesion on his perianal skin, as well as lesions on his groin and axilla. His labs showed elevated troponin levels, and a cardiac catheterization showed 60% stenosis of his RCA and 30% stenosis of his LCx.

The patient was prescribed the following medications at discharge: ASA, statin, and beta blocker. ||endoftext||

||startoftext||The patient is a 54-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital due to hypoxia after undergoing tumor debridement via rigid bronchoscopy. She has a history of renal cell carcinoma, which was diagnosed in the past and has since metastasized to her lungs. She has undergone multiple chemotherapy regimens, including gemcitabine and sunitinib, and is currently taking these medications. 

The patient's past medical history includes osteoarthritis of her lower spine, asthma, cluster migraines, and left renal cell carcinoma. She has also had a history of migraines, which were treated with sumatriptan. 

During her hospital stay, the patient underwent a rigid bronchoscopy with cryotherapy and electrocautery to open her airways and improve her breathing. After the procedure, she developed shortness of breath and likely had a blockage of her airway from a mucous plug or blood clot. She was admitted to the ICU for non-invasive ventilation and respiratory monitoring, and her breathing improved overnight. 

The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma with metastases and post-procedure respiratory distress secondary to airway plugging. She was prescribed several medications, including albuterol, ipratropium bromide, levothyroxine, omeprazole, sunitinib, and Tylenol Extra Strength. She was also advised to follow up in clinic in one month with a CT scan of her airways. ||endoftext||

gold_summary:
||startoftext||The patient is a 45-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with hematemesis. She has a history of EtOH abuse and cirrhosis, and has undergone several paracenteses and EGDs in the past. She was actively drinking and presented to the emergency department with six episodes of hematemesis, as well as worsening abdominal pain, acute reaccumulation of ascites, and poor appetite. 

Upon admission, her physical exam revealed a pale and distended abdomen, and she was started on octreotide and pantoprazole. She was transferred to the MICU and intubated for an emergent EGD. 

Her past medical history includes EtOH abuse, EtOH cirrhosis, hypertension, and a history of liver disease. She has also had several admissions for decompensation due to ascites and has undergone several paracenteses and EGDs. 

Her discharge medications include octreotide, pantoprazole, and lactulose. ||endoftext||

||startoftext||The patient is a 49-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital for a left renal mass. He presented with intense abdominal bloating and pain radiating up into his chest, which was initially thought to be related to gallbladder disease but was later found to be suspicious for renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The patient underwent a robot-assisted laparoscopic left partial nephrectomy and was discharged in stable condition.

The patient has no significant past medical history, allergies, or adverse reactions. His diagnosis is left kidney tumor, and he was prescribed medications for pain management, including acetaminophen and hydrocodone-acetaminophen. He was also given instructions to follow up with his urologist in three weeks and to avoid certain activities, such as lifting or driving, until then.

The patient's discharge condition is stable and improved, and he was given instructions on how to care for his incision and manage his pain. ||endoftext||

gold_summary: ||startoftext||The patient is an 87-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital for left toe gangrene. She has a past medical history of peripheral vascular disease, coronary artery disease, diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and left lower extremity ischemic disease. She was previously treated with revascularization and had a two-week outpatient course of Augmentin before being admitted for amputation of the left toe. The patient underwent a left toe amputation and tolerated the procedure well without complications. She was discharged one week after surgery and was prescribed medications including digoxin, NPH, isosorbide mononitrate, ketoconazole, levothyroxine, metoprolol, omeprazole, prednisone, simvastatin, acetaminophen, docusate sodium, lisinopril, nitroglycerin, warfarin, and clindamycin. The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician and to contact the office if she experiences any bleeding, redness, or drainage from the foot wound, new pain, numbness, or discoloration of the skin on the affected foot, or fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or pus draining from the incision site. ||endoftext||

gold_summary:
||startoftext||The patient is a 75-year-old female who was admitted with a chief complaint of left thigh bleeding. She has a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, COPD, and prior DVT. She was previously treated with Lovenox and was admitted to the hospital with an arterial bleed into her thigh, which required embolization of the left medial femoral circumflex artery. The patient's bleeding resolved with the application of Surgicel and direct pressure, but she experienced recurrent bleeding when she got up to use the bathroom. A CT scan revealed a fluid collection with surrounding stranding, consistent with an abscess. The patient was treated with antibiotics and was advised to remain non-weightbearing. She was also prescribed medications including acetaminophen, furosemide, levothyroxine, and valacyclovir.

The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension, hypothyroidism, COPD, and prior DVT. She also has a history of breast cancer, asthma, and ocular herpes. Her social history is significant for a motor vehicle accident in which she believes part of her skull was removed.

The patient's physical examination revealed a firm hematoma in her left upper thigh, as well as a chronic appearing wound with no active bleeding. Her vital signs were stable, and her laboratory results showed a decrease in her hemoglobin level. The patient was advised to remain non-weightbearing and to follow up with her primary care physician for further evaluation and treatment. ||endoftext||

||startoftext||The patient is a 61-year-old male who was admitted for evaluation of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) and a right eye plaque. He has a history of syncope, chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes, coronary artery disease, diabetic retinopathy, gastroesophageal reflux disease, hyperlipidemia, gout, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. He has no history of neurologic conditions in his family. 

The patient's physical examination was normal, with no focal neurological deficits. His laboratory results showed elevated blood glucose and urea nitrogen levels, as well as mild right ventricular hypertrophy on echocardiogram. 

The patient's MRI brain was negative for stroke, and his MRA neck showed no evidence of high-grade stenosis or occlusion. He was diagnosed with a TIA and was started on dual antiplatelet therapy to reduce the risk of subsequent emboli. ||endoftext||

||startoftext||The patient is a 45-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain and diarrhea. She has a history of EtOH cirrhosis, diverticulosis, and hypertension. Her symptoms began 2 days ago and worsened, prompting her to seek medical attention. She has had previous visits to the emergency department and one hospitalization for abdominal pain. 

The patient's past medical history includes EtOH abuse, EtOH cirrhosis, and hypertension. She has also had previous paracenteses and has a history of withdrawal seizures. 

On admission, the patient's physical examination revealed diffuse abdominal tenderness with pronounced rebound, and laboratory results showed mild liver dysfunction and anemia. 

The patient underwent a diagnostic paracentesis, which revealed 1 PMN. She was initially treated with cipro/flagyl, but the medications were discontinued due to low suspicion of infection. 

The patient's discharge medications include metronidazole 500mg PO, ceftriaxone 1g IV, and albumin 5% 25g IV. She was also prescribed lactulose and famotidine. 

The patient has a history of allergies to epinephrine and has had previous reactions to it. ||endoftext||

gold_summary:
||startoftext||The patient is a 58-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain. She had a history of recurrent metastatic ovarian cancer and had undergone multiple surgeries and chemotherapy treatments. She was initially diagnosed with stage IIC ovarian cancer and had received carboplatin and Taxol therapy until she developed a carboplatin allergy. She was then switched to Doxil and later started on Arimidex. She had been stable until she developed abdominal pain, concern for acute appendicitis, and underwent laparoscopic evaluation, which revealed several carcinoma implants along both hemidiaphragms, the right lobe of the liver, and the lower abdomen on the sigmoid colon and appendix.

The patient underwent exploratory laparotomy with extended right colectomy and end ileostomy. She was found to have small bowel pneumatosis and was placed on broad-spectrum antibiotics due to concern for sepsis. She was also found to have rising CA-125 levels and was initiated on carboplatin therapy. However, she developed a carboplatin allergy and was switched to Doxil.

The patient's past medical history is significant for recurrent metastatic ovarian cancer, osteopenia, and a family history of CAD and ovarian cancer. Her physical exam revealed abdominal tenderness, absent bowel sounds, and a Foley catheter in place draining clear urine.

The patient's discharge medications included vanc/zosyn, and her discharge labs showed elevated WBC count, AST, and ALT levels. Her imaging studies revealed a partially rim-enhancing fluid collection within the anterior midline abdomen, no findings of bowel obstruction or leak, and bibasilar atelectasis with small left pleural effusion.

In summary, the patient is a 58-year-old female with a history of recurrent metastatic ovarian cancer who underwent exploratory laparotomy with extended right colectomy and end ileostomy due to abdominal pain and concern for acute appendicitis. She was found to have small bowel pneumatosis and was placed on broad-spectrum antibiotics due to concern for sepsis. She was also found to have rising CA-125 levels and was initiated on carboplatin therapy, but developed a carboplatin allergy and was switched to Doxil. ||endoftext||

gold_summary:
||startoftext||The patient is an 81-year-old male who presented with a syncopal episode after a baseball game. He has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) with recent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), chronic heart failure (CHF), end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, hypertension (HTN), and atrial fibrillation (Afib). He was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation and treatment.

Upon admission, the patient's vital signs were notable for a temperature of 97.2Â°F, heart rate of 52 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 151/48 mmHg. His physical examination revealed a bradycardic rhythm, normal rhythm, and a III/VI holosystolic murmur heard throughout the precordium.

Laboratory results showed elevated levels of troponin (0.53 ng/mL) and creatinine (11.0 mg/dL), as well as mild anemia (Hgb 11.3 g/dL). Imaging studies revealed severe aortic stenosis with a valve area of 1.0 cmÂ² or less, as well as mild degenerative changes in the ankle joints.

The patient was prescribed medications at discharge, including Eliquis for Afib and metoprolol tartrate for hypertension. He was also advised to undergo evaluation for surgical or transcatheter intervention for severe aortic stenosis, continue hemodialysis three times a week, and consider stopping metoprolol tartrate due to bradycardia.

Overall, the patient's hospital course was marked by a syncopal episode likely due to a vagal episode in the setting of severe aortic stenosis, and he was discharged with recommendations for further evaluation and treatment. ||endoftext||

gold_summary:
||startoftext||The patient is a 45-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with sepsis. He initially presented to the emergency department with perforated appendicitis, which was complicated by an abscess that was drained twice. He was treated with antibiotics and discharged, but two weeks later, he returned to the hospital with sepsis and was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU). 

The patient has a history of MRSA abscess on his arm and a previous appendectomy complicated by an abscess. He has no known allergies to drugs. 

On admission, the patient's physical examination revealed an ill-appearing individual with a temperature of 98.4Â°F, blood pressure of 129/67 mmHg, and a heart rate of 88 beats per minute. His abdomen was soft, nontender, and nondistended, with well-healed laparoscopic scars. 

Laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 24.7, lactate level of 1.8, and troponin level of 0.29. He was treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin, levofloxacin, and ceftriaxone, and was started on a norepinephrine drip. 

The patient's diagnosis was sepsis, and he was managed non-surgically. He was discharged with a plan for continued antibiotic therapy and follow-up. ||endoftext||

||startoftext||The patient is a 43-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of left lower quadrant pain. She has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and recurrent skin abscesses. She was diagnosed with a tubo-ovarian abscess and underwent an IV-guided drainage procedure. During her hospital stay, she was treated with antibiotics and her condition improved. She was discharged with a diagnosis of tubo-ovarian abscess and was prescribed medications including acetaminophen, levofloxacin, metronidazole, atenolol, losartan, and metformin. She was advised to follow up with her doctor and to take her medications as prescribed. ||endoftext||

||startoftext||The patient is a 65-year-old female who presented with abdominal pain. She reported a 2-week history of general malaise, upper respiratory tract infection, and decreased appetite. She also experienced severe abdominal pain, which began while she was sitting on the couch, and had not had a bowel movement or flatus in 2 days. She vomited non-bloody, non-bilious emesis shortly after eating.

The patient has no known allergies or adverse reactions. She has no past medical history, past surgical history, or family history of note.

The patient's physical examination revealed a soft, tender abdomen with focal rebound and guarding. Laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, blood urea nitrogen, and creatinine levels, as well as abnormal liver function tests.

The patient underwent a diagnostic laparoscopy, which revealed a gastric perforation. She was converted to an exploratory laparotomy and underwent repair of the perforation with a patch and placement of a Pravena vac.

The patient was prescribed medications at discharge, but the specific medications are not mentioned in the report. ||endoftext||

||startoftext||The patient is a 45-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of an incisional hernia. He had a history of prolactinoma, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He also had a past surgical history of incarcerated umbilical hernia repair and cornea surgery. The patient had an allergy to amoxicillin.

The patient was diagnosed with an abdominal incisional hernia with obstruction and underwent a laparoscopic incisional hernia repair with graft or prosthesis. He was prescribed Percocet for pain and Colace for constipation.

At discharge, the patient was stable and was instructed to follow up with his surgeon. He was advised to avoid lifting objects greater than 5 pounds, driving, and operating heavy machinery while taking pain medications. He was also instructed to resume his regular home medications and take any new medications as ordered. ||endoftext||
gen_summary: Note this case file has been updated at age 46 years old.        Note these comments were added following review of  patient history:   Patient last update date = October 16th,2017 at age 43yrs   Comment Added After Review Of Patient's Case File:   This comment should explain why Mr.P. received so many prescription drugs during treatment; it also explains how much pain patients feel because they don't understand what the doctors mean by prescriptions being filled "at room temperature". We've provided more details about this topic here.      We know we're going to get some questions related to our website and its purpose? That's OK! Let me answer them one-by-one...   "Is there anything wrong with my information?" - The site doesn't store personal info such as name/address/email/etc... Just like Facebook, Twitter etc.... All data entered into our system only goes back up-to-date once each month.   "The page took long-time to load." I'm sorry if you encountered issues loading pages with high traffic volumes. But please check again since most cases can be fixed quickly. Check out our FAQ section where possible answers might already exist!   "How do you write accurate diagnoses based-on limited medical knowledge without knowing everything!" I believe we covered this pretty nicely above. Do try reading through articles carefully though. Also note that physicians make mistakes too which results in different diagnosis/diseases having same names.   How To Write A Good Diagnosis Article?   I wrote similar article just two weeks ago called 'Diagnosis Articles For Beginners'. Feel free to read-through using link below!   https://www.williamsburg.com/how-do-i-write-a-good-diagnostic-article-for-beginners/   It's unfortunate sometimes that people tend to assume the worst whenever someone tries to help them. My goal isn't to discourage anyone from trying something else. Instead, it'd better serve us instead of hurting others who genuinely need assistance.   Thanks for sharing thoughts!

She has allergies to Augmentin.

The patient's chief complaint was non-healing wounds, and she underwent a wound vac placement to the left groin and a left AV graft thrombectomy. She was also treated for MRSA and corynebacterium infections.

The patient's diagnosis was not explicitly stated, but it appears that she had a wound infection and possibly a graft infection. She underwent several procedures, including a wound vac placement, a left AV graft thrombectomy, and a thrombectomy and venoplasty.

At discharge, the patient was prescribed the following medications: vancomycin, zosyn, and prednisone. She was advised to continue physical therapy in rehab to regain her mobility. ||endoftext||

||startoftext||The patient is a 58-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of weight loss. He has a history of Crohn's disease, multiple laparotomies, and short gut syndrome, which has led to complications such as intermittent small bowel obstruction and dependence on total parenteral nutrition (TPN). He also has a history of chronic abdominal pain, depression, and anxiety. On admission, his physical examination revealed a diffusely tender abdomen with mild rebound tenderness, and his laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, neutrophil count, and C-reactive protein. He was diagnosed with a possible small bowel obstruction and was treated with nebulizer therapy and oral steroids. At discharge, his vital signs were stable, and his physical examination revealed a mild firmness and diffusely tender abdomen. His laboratory results showed improvement in his white blood cell count and C-reactive protein, but his albumin and calcium levels remained low. He was prescribed medications for his chronic pain and was advised to follow up with his primary care physician.

Note: The patient's allergies and adverse reactions are listed as codeine and penicillins. ||endoftext||
gen_summary: ___     ### Output:  #### Allergy Codeines/Penicillinls [Codeine]__|[[Penicilin]]_   ##### _ None_  ## Table Of Contents ##  ### Header ## ```markdown --- title: Medline Articles For Treatment Of Patients With Idiopathic Chronic Pulmonary ObstructivE Syndrome And Hypercapnic Respiratory Failure From Lung Transplantation By Use Of Percutaneous Endoscopic Thoracostomy Ventilation Technique To Improve Clinical Outcome, Quality Of Life And Length Of Stay After Adult Single-Lung Transplants ---  --- ```  ## Abstract##  ###### **Background** :Â  Idiopathic chronic pulmonary obstructive syndrome (CPPOS). Patients receiving lung transplantation undergo intensive ventilation support for prevention of complications associated with CPPOS such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), long-term mechanical ventilatory dependence, prolonged duration of oxygen supplementation, and poor outcomes secondary to severe hypercarbia. These patients often suffer extreme suffering caused by their condition resulting in significant physical impairment. Our objective is to provide empirical data regarding the role of percutaneous endoscopic thoracic aspiration (PETTA) technique in improving the quality-of-life outcome of patients undergoing elective adult unilateral-lung transplant surgery using PETAs rather than conventional methods of lung ventilation. Therefore, prospective study design involving institutional review board approval of participants and obtaining written informed consent from each participant is required according to international standards established by various professional organizations.    ###### Â Â MethodsÂ Â  We designed a randomized control trial comparing PETTa vs Conventional method of anesthesia with regard to peri-operative mortality rates between groups. For ethical considerations, neither experimental nor control group participants received standard intravenous anaesthesia administered concurrently either preoperatively, during induction phase of the procedure or immediately after completion of surgical procedures.    ###### Key words : Perfuential Exhaled Air; Percutaneuos ET; Thraconchaeal Ascari; Veical Pastral Ascariatry; Permeability Facilitatioun; Venue Requisition; Respiyorial Impoement; Quality Of Lifoe Outcom ; Mortality Rate; Death Moralety Rates ; Ventilaun Support ; Post Operative Moraliety;  Clinical Practice Guidelines (CPGs); Guidelines Development;   Concurrent Decision Making Process;    Data Collection Methods :    Information Extraction:    Study Design Selection Criteria :   Selection criteria include those factors necessary for inclusion or exclusion from the analysis.      Key Performance Indicators:   Performance indicators measure effectiveness as opposed to efficiency.

gold_summary: ||startoftext||The patient is a 55-year-old male who was admitted to the hospital with a rapidly progressive syndrome of back and radiating leg pain, progressive lower extremity weakness, and the progressive loss of the ability to walk. He underwent a lumbar posterior decompression procedure without complication. The patient has a history of allergies to Ibuprofen, Penicillins, Sulfa, and Latex. His past medical history is significant for spinal stenosis, and he has a family history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obstructive sleep apnea. The patient was prescribed several medications at discharge, including acetaminophen, docusate sodium, oxycodone, hydrochlorothiazide, finasteride, and tamsulosin. He was advised to follow a normal diet, avoid lifting heavy objects, and to ambulate as tolerated. The patient was discharged home with instructions to follow up with his doctor and to take his medications as directed. ||endoftext||

||startoftext||The patient is a 68-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital for an elective resection of a left lower lobe carcinoid tumor. She has a history of anxiety, which causes her to experience symptoms such as cough, palpitations, and gastrointestinal complaints. She also has a history of migraine with aura, hemorrhoids, and retinal detachment. The patient has allergies to iodine and latex.

The patient underwent a left video-assisted basilar segmentectomy and tolerated the procedure well. She was given pain medication and was able to transition to oral pain medication. The patient was also given prophylactic heparin and was encouraged to ambulate and get up as early as possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile, and tolerating a regular diet. She was prescribed several medications, including acetaminophen, losartan, hydrochlorothiazide, fluticasone, simvastatin, omeprazole, oxycodone, lorazepam, docusate sodium, magnesium hydroxide, and zolpidem.

The patient was discharged home with instructions to follow up with her doctor if she experiences any symptoms such as fever, shortness of breath, or chest pain. She was also advised to take acetaminophen for pain and to avoid lifting heavy objects or engaging in strenuous activities until her incision has fully healed. ||endoftext||
